fields.descriptive_line: Portrait miniature of an unknown man, watercolour on vellum, painted by monogrammist J.L., 1675-1680.
fields.physical_description:
Portrait of a man, head and shoulders, turned slightly to left, looking to front, wearing a long wig and neckcloth tied in a bow.  Features in short hatches of very gummy dark brown and sanguine, with touches of black and white heightening in the eyes, on a pale carnation ground; hair in brown wash with gummy dark brown hatching and some lights in pale gouache, also over the carnation; cravat in pale grey wash, modelled in pale grey and black and with the lights in white; costume in brown washes, modelled in very gummy dark brown; background in brown wash hatched with darker colour, darkening to the right of the head; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. 

<u>Frame:</u> Nineteenth-century silver-gilt locket, convex back and with sides with multiple step moulding sloping into a push-fit rim with a bezel, which holds the flat glass by its bevelled edge; the hanger of square section, channelled down the middle.
fields.title: An Unknown Man
fields.materials_techniques: Watercolour on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book
fields.bibliography: Murdoch, John. Seventeenth-century English Miniatures in the collection of the Victoria and Albert Museum. London: The Stationery Office, 1997. Full citation, pp.301-302: “J L The identity of the artist 'J L' has attracted considerable speculation. Long, who bought the following miniature for the Museum, must have wanted it because he recognised in the artist a very interesting hand, confident in deploying an unconventional colour range and in modelling characterful features with accuracy and power. His only surviving note, however, was to relate the artist to the scholar J L who translated Willem Goeree's Inleydinge tot de algemeene Teyken-Konst in 1678. (1) According to the British Library Catalogue of Printed Books, this scholar J L was Johann Lange, a physician of Hamburg, credited with an impressive bibliography that does not quite correspond, however, with that attributed to him by Long, (2) and with interests that relate generally to those of Goeree as well as to those of other physicians who turned their mind to limning (for example Turquet de Mayerne). (3) These considerations lend support to Long's identification of J L, but the hand in this case is so deft and 'practised' that it suggests a more committed interest in limning than that of a very productive natural philosopher. In addition, the technique is conventionally English, apart from the gumminess which would be even more exceptional elsewhere in Europe. Accordingly, Jim Murrell suggested (4) that J L could have been John Lambert (d.1701), son of the Parliamentary General, who was said by the antiquarian Ralph Thoresby to be 'a most exact limner'. (5) Thoresby and Lambert were fellow members of the York 'Virtuosi', one of the provincial societies which grew up in the seventeenth century under the influence of Baconian natural philosophy, closely analogous to the Royal Society in London, and with a similar range of interests including the art and craft of painting. (6) Other artists within the York Virtuosi were Jacques Parmentier (1658-1730), William Lodge (1649-1689), Francis Place (1647-1728) and Henry Gyles (1645-1709), who owned the Norgate/Hoskins MS Art of Limning. (7) Lambert has been suggested as a possible author of the chalk and water-colour portrait of Gyles in the British Museum. (8) But no certain work by him survives, and the present miniature remains the solitary exemplar of the monogrammist J L. Technically there is no similarity between the miniature and the BM drawing. 1 On Goeree, see Cross, Cat. No. 166 and Murdoch 1981, pp. 160-1. 2 Long, for example, attributed to him a translation of Kenelm Digby's Demonstratio immortalitatis animae rationalis (1655); N Knatchbull's Annotations upon some difficult texts in ... the New Testament (1693); An exact abridgement of that ... treatise called Doctor and Student, by C Saint Germain (1658); as well as a translation into Latin of F Bayle, Dissertatio de Causa suspensione vaporem in aere (1701). The BL list includes translations of N Flamel, Des berühmten ... N Flamelli chymische Wercke (1681), E G Happel, Thesaurus exoticorum ... Wie auch Mahomets ... Alkoran (1688), E Kelly, E Kellaei . Tractatus duo ... de Lapide Philosophorum (1676), C Lancillotti, Der brennende Salamander (1681), and A Belin, Die Wunderlichen Begebenheiten des Unbekandten Philosophi in Such-und Findung des Steins derWeisen(1673). 3 On whom see Murdoch 1981, pp. 107-9; HughTrevor-Roper, Lord Dacre, has also been working on a major study of Turquet de Mayerne. 4 Personal communication, 1992. 5 DNB. 6 See biographical note on Thomas Flatman (q. v.) ; and for the York connections of the Coopers, see biographical notes on Samuel and Alexander, also in this volume. 7 BL Harleian MS 6376. 8 Croft-Murray and Hulton 1960, vol.I, pp. 342-3, vol. II, pl. 138. Cat.180, p. 302. Full citation: 180 Unknown Man c. 1675-80 P34-1933 Oval 65.5 x 55 mm Features in short hatches of very gummy dark brown and sanguine, with touches of black and white heightening in the eyes, on a pale carnation ground; hair in brown wash with gummy dark brown hatching and some lights in pale gouache, also over the carnation; cravat in pale grey wash, modelled in pale grey and black and with the lights in white; costume in brown washes, modelled in very gummy dark brown; background in brown wash hatched with darker colour, darkening to the right of the head; on vellum put down on a leaf from a table-book. Condition: Flaking overall, especially in the upper and right margins; some old retouches, including probably some or much of the superfluous gum; vellum lifting especially in the lower margin; the gesso of the table-book leaf deteriorated, presumably through damp. Signed: Lower right, in gold: JL (see A in Appendix 2). Inscribed on the back in graphite: No (?), and another illegible word. Frame: Nineteenth-century silver-gilt locket, convex back and with sides with multiple step moulding sloping into a push-fit rim with a bezel, which holds the flat glass by its bevelled edge; the hanger of square section, channelled down the middle. Provenance: Christie's 11 December 1933, lot 66, 'the property of a collector ... from the collection of the Duke of Leinster', dated 1680; bt for the Museum with funds from the R H Stephenson Bequest. Literature: Accessions 1933, p. 63; V&A, Review of the Principal Acquisitions, 1934, p. 22, pl. 14c; Foskett 1972, vol. I, p. 368 (following Long, see below, but giving the artist's name without explanation as J CL) . On the evidence of the style of the miniature - the short hatching strokes and stippling, but with a distinct impasto in the blending of gouache into the features, 'wiped' around the eye-sockets - the artist could have been taught by Richard Gibson. On costume and hairstyle, the date is about 1675-80."
fields.credit: Purchased with funds from the Stephenson Bequest
fields.history_note: <u>Provenance:</u> Christie's 11 December 1933, lot 66, 'the property of a collector ... from the collection of the Duke of Leinster', dated 1680; bt for the Museum with funds from the R H Stephenson Bequest.
